docs.snippet: France, Sweden, and Serbia and Montenegro clinched Europe's three remaining automatic berths for next year's World Cup finals in Germany.
docs.lead_paragraph: France, Sweden, and Serbia and Montenegro clinched Europe's three remaining automatic berths for next year's World Cup finals in Germany. France defeated Cyprus, 4-0, to win Group 4 yesterday, and Serbia and Montenegro defeated its neighbor Bosnia and Herzegovina, 1-0, for first place in Group 7.

headline.main: World Cup Field Takes Shape, And France Leads the Parade

docs.snippet: The Chilean sea bass has become a cause, an all-but-forbidden entree, the plunder of pirates  and the fish story of our times.
docs.lead_paragraph: On a dank, cold morning this past March, full of wind and the gloom of the sub-Antarctic autumn, I stepped off the customs pier in the Falkland Islands port of Stanley and tried to board a pirate ship. The Elqui, a rusted-out heap flying the Guinean flag, sat impounded at the dock, her captain awaiting charges from the British territorial government of South Georgia Island. What had brought the Elqui and its 30-odd Indonesian, African and South American crew members to this remote harbor at the bottom of the world were Chilean sea bass, 13 tons of which now lay frozen below the ship's deck.

docs.snippet: Two men bought a fixer-upper in Bedford-Stuyvesant for themselves and, later, their Bergamasco sheepdogs. The house cost $376,000. Renovating it cost another $300,000.
docs.lead_paragraph: EVERYBODY on their block of Lexington Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant seems to know Erik Rothman, 34, and Juan-Manuel Olivera-Silvera, 33. Their neighbors know them as the couple who poured hundreds of thousands of dollars into a derelict 1899 town house. They know them as the guys who always seem to be walking their two long-haired Bergamasco sheepdogs and packing them into their S.U.V. to play in Prospect Park. They know them as the conspicuous Caucasians in a mostly West Indian area.
docs.abstract: Habitats column on Erik Rothman and Juan-Manue Olivera-Silvera's Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, townhouse bought through Dept of Housing and Urban Development auction; couple paid $376,000 for 1899 townhouse, and through purchase-and-renovation mortgage was able to have funds for renovations available as work proceeded; photos (M)

multimedia.credit: A couple describe their $300,000 renovation to restore a Brooklyn brownstone to its 40's roots.

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: A couple describe their $300,000 renovation to restore a Brooklyn brownstone to its 40's roots.

multimedia.caption: A Brownstone Called Home

headline.main: HABITATS/Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn; 2 Guys, 2 Sheepdogs, A Flock of Neighbors

docs.snippet: Decades ago, two brothers who rarely speak to each other bet on Bordeux's future. Now the Lurtons may be the region's last great dynasty.
docs.lead_paragraph: One day in 1992, Lucien Lurton, then the owner of Château Brane-Cantenac, a major estate in the village of Margaux, France, called together his 10 children. Over the previous 40 years, Lurton had become one of the largest and wealthiest landowners in Bordeaux, and now, he told his family, he was going to divide his holdings -- 11 wine chateaus and their vineyards -- among them.

docs.snippet: A two-day summit meeting of leaders of 34 Western Hemisphere nations in Argentina, attended by President Bush, broke up Saturday without a clear agreement on when and how to resume stalled talks aimed at achieving a hemispherewide free trade...
docs.lead_paragraph: A two-day summit meeting of leaders of 34 Western Hemisphere nations in Argentina, attended by President Bush, broke up Saturday without a clear agreement on when and how to resume stalled talks aimed at achieving a hemispherewide free trade agreement. Mr. Bush had hoped to persuade his counterparts from Latin America and the Caribbean to deliver a resounding endorsement of the plan, the Free Trade Area of the Americas. But suspicions of American intentions prevailed in the end, and by late Saturday no final communiqué had been issued.

headline.main: Hemisphere Meeting Ends Without Trade Consensus

byline.original: By LARRY ROHTER and ELISABETH BUMILLER

docs.snippet: Through all the ups and downs of the Los Angeles Galaxy's 32 regular-season and 3 playoff games, the team has had one constant - defender Todd Dunivant.
docs.lead_paragraph: Through all the ups and downs of the Los Angeles Galaxy's 32 regular-season and 3 playoff games, Coach Steve Sampson has had one constant -- defender Todd Dunivant. ''Ironman? I'll take that label,'' Dunivant said in a telephone interview Sunday, the day after the Galaxy defeated the Colorado Rapids to advance to next Sunday's M.L.S. Cup against the New England Revolution at Pizza Hut Park in Frisco, Tex.

headline.main: Defender Has Been The Galaxy's Rock

docs.snippet: GOLF    WOODS TRAILS BY ONE STROKE -- Tiger Woods, playing his first official stroke-play event in China, shot a five-under-par 67 yesterday and will enter the final round of the HSBC Champions tournament in Shanghai a stroke behind the leader, David...
docs.lead_paragraph: GOLF WOODS TRAILS BY ONE STROKE -- Tiger Woods, playing his first official stroke-play event in China, shot a five-under-par 67 yesterday and will enter the final round of the HSBC Champions tournament in Shanghai a stroke behind the leader, David Howell.

docs.snippet: Chris Rolfe, drafted by Chicago from the University of Dayton, traveled to Scotland for his first international match for the United States.
docs.lead_paragraph: If Chris Rolfe were a rock star, the DVD of his first professional season would be called the Eye-Opening Tour '05. Rolfe was drafted by Chicago of Major League Soccer out of the University of Dayton, led the Fire during the regular season with eight goals (including an impressive score in a friendly against A.C. Milan of Italy) and finished second in voting for rookie of the year. All that for a starting salary of $16,500, which rose to $30,000 midway through the season.

docs.snippet: Diplomatic relations between Mexico and Venezuela fell apart after President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela refused to apologize for remarks about President Vicente Fox of Mexico.
docs.lead_paragraph: Diplomatic relations between Mexico and Venezuela fell apart Monday after President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela refused to apologize for remarks about President Vicente Fox of Mexico. The two heads of state have been at loggerheads since this month's Summit of the Americas in Argentina, where Mr. Fox defended an American-backed proposal for a free trade zone throughout the Americas while Mr. Chávez declared it dead. Violent protests against the idea raged in the streets of Mar del Plata, Argentina, during the talks.
docs.abstract: Diplomatic relations between Mexico and Venezuela fall apart after Pres Hugo Chavez refuses to apologize for calling Pres Vicente Fox 'puppy dog' of United States; two have been at loggerheads since recent Summit of the Americas, where Fox defended American-backed proposal for free trade zone throughout Americas while Chavez declared it dead; rift between Mexico and Venezuela reflects wider gap between Canada, US and Mexico on one side and Latin American left-wing leaders who reject Pres Bush's call for more free trade, preferring to strengthen their trade ties with China and European Union (M)

headline.main: Name-Calling Erodes Ties Between Fox And Chávez

docs.snippet: Trinidad and Tobago, the Czech Republic, Spain, Switzerland, and Australia joined the field of 32 on the final day of qualifying.
docs.lead_paragraph: Trinidad and Tobago and the Czech Republic advanced to the World Cup for the first time yesterday with victories in the final day of qualifying, which began 26 months ago. Spain qualified for its eighth straight tournament as the final five berths in the 32-nation field were filled, while Switzerland ousted Turkey, a 2002 semifinalist, and Australia beat Uruguay to advance for the first time since 1974 and become the first nation to qualify for a World Cup through a penalty-kick shootout.
docs.abstract: Trinidad and Tobago defeats Bahrain, 1-0, to qualify for World Cup for first time (M)5

headline.main: It's On to Germany For Final 5 Qualifiers
